commit_message:
Split slow rally job to several small ones

Job gate-rally-dsvm-rally does check rally scenarios for all openstack
services. This takes almost one hour.

Here we move heat, cinder and nova scenarios to separate jobs. So we
will have 5 jobs instead of 2.

Change-Id: I6fbae8240311540588b13adbadc4338067d6c618

subject: Run db_sync when heat-common is upgraded
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-06 12:35:09.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/init.pp', 'spec/classes/heat_init_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat/commit/bfa9f0aa3e9dfc6dd50a000bf59c06feb07144e8', 'message': "Run db_sync when heat-common is upgraded

The other packages appear to already have this, but heat-common isn't
triggering a db sync, and at least on Ubuntu, if this package is
upgraded first, all the others get pulled in also.  When that happens,
Puppet doesn't trigger a notification for the other packages and the db
sync is never run.

Change-Id: I454220ee6c501c416b60564fd3b1f00fdecfd296
"}]
commit_message:
Run db_sync when heat-common is upgraded

The other packages appear to already have this, but heat-common isn't
triggering a db sync, and at least on Ubuntu, if this package is
upgraded first, all the others get pulled in also.  When that happens,
Puppet doesn't trigger a notification for the other packages and the db
sync is never run.

Change-Id: I454220ee6c501c416b60564fd3b1f00fdecfd296
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat refs/changes/16/189016/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'has db_sync enabled' do is_expected.to contain_exec('heat-dbsync').with( :subscribe => 'Package[heat-common]', ) end

commit_message:
The Tenant subnet dic and the Routes were pointing to the same Subnet
Object, that caused problems and sync issues
Modify the subnets dic in the router class to be a list of the subnet
ids connected to this router.
Accessing the object is from the Tenant main subnets dic

Change-Id: I193b201132f5a7d524833ba03804886b48967745
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/13/188413/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.subnets = [] self.subnets.append(subnet.id) self.subnets.remove(subnet.id) subnet = tenant.subnets[subnet_info.id] subnet = subnets[subnet_info['id']] #TODO(gampel) Are we sure we want to delete the subnet #We Need to make sure that it is not needed for #L2 VM to VM proactive flow install for subnet_id in router.subnets: subnet = tenant.subnets[subnet_id] subnet, interface)
deleted_lines: self.subnets = {} self.subnets[subnet.id] = subnet del self.subnets[subnet.id] subnet = router.subnets[subnet_info['id']] subnet = router_old.subnets[subnet_info['id']] for subnet in router.subnets.values(): subnet, interface)

commit_message:
Enforce usage of project scoped token

In order for functionality to remain intact (ie disallow people to create / do
actions in designate that ends up with a "None" tenant_id as the owner in the
db) we need to enforce the use of a project scoped token for now.

Closes-Bug: #1460187

Change-Id: I8a64fe4938b3b9b0ade9fe210e4da0d19ad1c23f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/70/187570/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if request.environ["context"].tenant is None: raise exceptions.Forbidden("A project scoped token is required")

commit_message:
Set owner of Q_VPN_CONF_FILE file to STACK_USER user

Functional tests need to have access to configuration files.
Since the tests are started under 'stack' user
(sudo -H -u stack tox -e dsvm-functional) it would be better
to change owner of the Q_VPN_CONF_FILE file to STACK_USER.

Change-Id: I1ca677a805872726667df641255201cdd4cf4037
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/02/186802/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo install -m 644 -o $STACK_USER $temp_ini $Q_VPN_CONF_FILE

commit_message:
Reenable test_list_servers_filtered_by_ip_regex

It seems that bug #1182883 which has been the reason to skip
test_list_servers_filtered_by_ip_regex has been resolved for some time.
So we reenable this test and only skip the ip6 part that is still
pending on #1450859.

Change-Id: I4e926496fe317daee3be3d8c62c90723a04a7e23
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/24/188024/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

# Adriana Chisco Landazábal , 2015"POT-Creation-Date: 2015-06-05 01:49-0500 " "PO-Revision-Date: 2015-06-05 22:42+0000 " "Last-Translator: Adriana Chisco Landazábal "msgid "" " " " Each of the Data Processing frameworks require a cluster of " "machines " " in order to do the work they are assigned. A cluster is " " formed by creating a set of Node Group Templates, " "combining " " those into a Cluster Template and then launching a " "Cluster. " " You can do each of those steps manually, or you can follow " " this guide to help take you through the steps of " " Cluster creation. " " " msgstr "" " " "Cada framwork del Procesamiento de Datos requiere un clúster de máquinas " "para poder realizar el trabajo que se les ha asignado. Un clúster se " "forma al crear un juego de Nodos de Grupos de Temas, combinándolos " "en un Tema de Clúster y luego ejecutando un Clúster. " "Puede realizar cada uno de estos pasos manualmente, o puede seguir " "esta guía que lo llevará a través de los pasos para la " "creación del Clúster." #, python-format msgid "" " " " %(volume_label)s on " "%(volume_device)s " " " msgstr "" " " "%(volume_label)s en %(volume_device)s" #, python-format msgid "" " " " %(instance_name)s on %(device)s " " " msgstr "" " " " %(instance_name)s en %(device)s " " " msgid "" " " " Change the volume type of a volume after its creation. " " This is equivalent to the cinder retype command. " " " msgstr "" " " " Cambie el tipo de volumen tras su creación. " " Esto equivale al comando cinder retype . " " " " Each QoS Specs entity will have a "Consumer" value which indicates " "where the " " administrator would like the QoS policy to be enforced. This value can " "be "front-end" " " (Nova Compute), "back-end" (Cinder back-end), or "both". " " " msgstr "" " " "Cada entidad de Especificaciones QoS tendrá un valor "Consumidor" que " "indicará donde " "el administrador desea que las políticas de QoS sean forzadas. Este valor " "puede ser "front-end" " "(Nova Compute), "back-end" (Cinder back-end), o "ambos"." msgid "" " "" Assign a name and description for the pool. Choose one subnet where all " " members of this pool must be on. Select the protocol and load balancing " " method for this pool. Admin State is UP (checked) by default. " " " msgstr "" " " " Asigne un nombre y descripción para el pool. Elija una subred en donde se " "encuentren todos " " los miembros de este pool. Seleccione el protocolo y método de balance de " "carga " " para este pool. El estado del administrador es ACTIVO (marcado) por " "defecto. " " " msgid "" " "msgid "%(stack_status_title)s: %(stack_status_reason)s" msgstr "%(stack_status_title)s: %(stack_status_reason)s" #, python-formatmsgid "" "A snapshot is an image which preserves the disk state of a running instance." msgstr "" "Una instantánea es una imagen que conserva el estado del disco de una " "instancia en ejecución." #, python-format msgid "ALLOW %(from)s:%(to)s/%(ip_protocol)s from %(cidr)s" msgstr "PERMITIR %(from)s:%(to)s/%(ip_protocol)s desde %(cidr)s" #, python-format msgid "ALLOW %(from)s:%(to)s/%(ip_protocol)s from %(group)s" msgstr "PERMITIR%(from)s:%(to)s/%(ip_protocol)s desde %(group)s" msgid "AWS compatible" msgstr "Compatible con AWS" msgid "Add Router Route" msgstr "Añadir ruta del router" msgid "Add Static Route" msgstr "Añadir rutas estáticas" msgid "Add route" msgstr "Añadir ruta" msgid "Add static route to the router." msgstr "Añadir ruta estática al router." msgid "" "Allocates requests to the instance with the least number of " " active connections." msgstr "" "Asignación de las solicitudes a las instancias con el menor número de " " conexiones activas." msgid "Associated Routers" msgstr "Enrutadores Asociados" msgid "Attach Interface" msgstr "Conectar interfaz" msgid "Attaching interface for instance %s." msgstr "Conectar interfaz para instancia%s." #, python-formatmsgctxt "current status of stack" msgid "Check Complete" msgstr "Marcar Finalizada" msgctxt "current status of stack" msgid "Check Failed" msgstr "Marcar Falló" msgctxt "current status of stack" msgid "Check In Progress" msgstr "Verificar en Progreso" "Choose router(s) from Available Routers to Selected Routers by push button " "or drag and drop. " msgstr "" "Escoja el(los) enrutador(es) de "Enrutadores Disponibles" a "Enrutadores " "Seleccionados" al pulsar un botón o al arrastrar y soltar." msgid ""msgid "" "Choose the rule you want to insert. Specify either the rule you want to " "insert immediately before, or the rule to insert immediately after. " " " msgstr "" "Fuentes de Datos son lo que " "su trabajo utiliza para la entrada y salida. Dependiendo del tipo " "de trabajo que estará realizando, deberá definir uno o más " "fuentes de datos. Puede crear múltiple fuentes " "de datos al repetir este paso." msgid "" "Define your Job Template. commit_message:
JSCS cleanup - Angular framework widgets (partial)

We need to do cleanup before we can enable JSCS globally
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/185725/).

Widgets included: action-list, charts, help-panel, magic-search,
metadata-display, metadata-tree.

Change-Id: I3b2f105946d4920c866bc60d0c4e970ef2994c33
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup

subject: Have conductors be disconnected from builder helper methods
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-20 22:14:20.000000000', 'files': ['taskflow/conductors/base.py', 'taskflow/conductors/backends/__init__.py', 'taskflow/conductors/backends/impl_blocking.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/5678473c01eb5dd482bb7bcfdb225d9ac0ca7651', 'message': 'Have conductors be disconnected from builder helper methods

Instead of having the methods that are used to create a engine,
flow detail or listener list be tightly bound to a conductor
create a helper object that contains just these strategies and
can be passed into conductor instances.

This reduces the conductor __init__ arguments and allows for these
types of strategies to be customized more easily (without having
to subclass).

This is a backwards incompatible change for users directly interacting
with the conductor classes (for example for those that are subclassing
them); but for those that are using the conductor fetch() entrypoint
this should be a compatible change that continues working as it previously
was.

Change-Id: I46e5d01af30b05be7deb4f5df1fd8218e02585ec
'}]
commit_message:
Have conductors be disconnected from builder helper methods

Instead of having the methods that are used to create a engine,
flow detail or listener list be tightly bound to a conductor
create a helper object that contains just these strategies and
can be passed into conductor instances.

This reduces the conductor __init__ arguments and allows for these
types of strategies to be customized more easily (without having
to subclass).

This is a backwards incompatible change for users directly interacting
with the conductor classes (for example for those that are subclassing
them); but for those that are using the conductor fetch() entrypoint
this should be a compatible change that continues working as it previously
was.

Change-Id: I46e5d01af30b05be7deb4f5df1fd8218e02585ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/98/166398/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, name, jobboard, builders, wait_timeout=None): super(BlockingConductor, self).__init__(name, jobboard, builders) def _dispatch_job(self, job): engine = self._builders.engine_from(job) listeners = self._builders.listeners_from(job, engine) if not listeners: listeners = [] # Always ensure that one is attached that logs the engines activites... listeners.insert(0, logging_listener.LoggingListener(engine, log=LOG))
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, name, jobboard, persistence=None, engine=None, engine_options=None, wait_timeout=None): super(BlockingConductor, self).__init__( name, jobboard, persistence=persistence, engine=engine, engine_options=engine_options) def _listeners_from_job(self, job, engine): listeners = super(BlockingConductor, self)._listeners_from_job(job, engine) listeners.append(logging_listener.LoggingListener(engine, log=LOG)) return listeners def _dispatch_job(self, job): engine = self._engine_from_job(job) listeners = self._listeners_from_job(job, engine)

commit_message:
Return provider_id in 3PAR volume model update

The provider_id field was added in
commit: 9f34d34d0ab92400223e3cc87285d0d4fbdf21f9
This patch adds provider_id to the returned model
update and uses it to provide the internal 3PAR
volume name mapping.

Change-Id: I00f1a159c036f9058305c278539a77b2df87f837

commit_message:
builddoc: allow to use fnmatch-style exclusion for autodoc

This allows to use patterns such as heat.tests.* to exlude modules from
autodoc genereation.

Change-Id: Ibfc4161670fd9344da88c4a85a3aea992fcdf519

commit_message:
doc: add some basic doc about pbr doc options

Change-Id: Iccb0ba35a008596cb63e1d6954bd9cb8fa50ae78
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/79/184879/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pbr --- The pbr section controls pbr specific options and behaviours. The `autodoc_tree_index_modules` is a boolean value controlling whether pbr should generate an index of modules using `sphinx-apidoc`. The `autodoc_index_modules` is a boolean option controlling whether pbr should itself generates documentation for Python modules of the project. By default, all found Python modules are included; some of them can be excluded by listing them in `autodoc_exclude_modules`.

added_lines: ======== Features ======== * A :py:class:`.futurist.GreenThreadPoolExecutor` using `eventlet`_ green thread pools. It provides a standard `executor`_ API/interface and it also gathers execution statistics. It returns instances of :py:class:`.futurist.GreenFuture` objects. * A :py:class:`.futurist.ProcessPoolExecutor` derivative that gathers execution statistics. It returns instances of :py:class:`.futurist.Future` objects. * A :py:class:`.futurist.SynchronousExecutor` that **doesn't** run concurrently. It has the same `executor`_ API/interface and it also gathers execution statistics. It returns instances of :py:class:`.futurist.Future` objects. * A :py:class:`.futurist.ThreadPoolExecutor` derivative that gathers execution statistics. It returns instances of :py:class:`.futurist.Future` objects. .. _eventlet: http://eventlet.net/ .. _executor: https://docs.python.org/dev/library/concurrent.futures.html#executor-objects

commit_message:
Attempt to use the monotonic pypi module if it's installed

Change-Id: I02e52827e3da15dc40b827579af5f7b9b2789c40
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/futurist refs/changes/82/188982/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time # Use monotonic time in stopwatches if we can get at it... # # PEP @ https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0418/ try: now = time.monotonic # no-qa except AttributeError: try: # Try to use the pypi module if it's available (optionally...) from monotonic import monotonic as now # no-qa except (AttributeError, ImportError): # Ok fallback to the non-monotonic one... now = time.time # no-qa
deleted_lines: try: from time import monotonic as now # noqa except ImportError: from time import time as now # noqa

commit_message:
Add entrypoints for option discovery

oslo-config-generator relies on entrypoints listed
in setup.cfg to add options to the generated sample conf
files in different projects. So expose options avaliable in
oslo.service using the following entrypoints:

* oslo.service.periodic_task
* oslo.service.service
* oslo.service.sslutils

The following commands can be used to generate sample conf:
tox -evenv -- oslo-config-generator --namespace oslo.service.periodic_task
tox -evenv -- oslo-config-generator --namespace oslo.service.service
tox -evenv -- oslo-config-generator --namespace oslo.service.sslutils

bp graduate-oslo-service
Change-Id: I61372047b70341e3536db21aa3f1bd9d99c08185
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.service refs/changes/07/187607/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [entry_points] oslo.config.opts = oslo.service = oslo_service._options:list_opts

commit_message:
Introduce abstract base class for services

Service object that is passed to any launcher must implement
the following methods:
    * start
    * stop
    * wait
    * reset

Introducing abstract base class from which all openstack
services that use common.service code can subclass guarantees it.

Added documentation for launcher classes in service.py

Change-Id: I79b38a354dd85f58a7c16b34661bff02d9170a9f
Closes-Bug: #1447965

commit_message:
More explicit data_files install location docs

Make it obvious to the reader that data_files installation target
location translates to the actual system-wide root filesystem tree
when installed with sufficient permissions to do so.

Change-Id: I67a4dc61ab89b96b4f5e1f99f0199e5a3247412a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/51/188451/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: in `/etc/init.d`. All of the files and directories located under `etc/pbr` in the source tree will be installed into `/etc/pbr`. Note that this behavior is relative to the effective root of the environment into which the packages are installed, so depending on available permissions this could be the actual system-wide `/etc` directory or just a top-level `etc` subdirectory of a virtualenv.
deleted_lines: in `/etc/init.d`. All of the files and directories located under `etc/pbr` in the source tree will be installed into `/etc/pbr`.

commit_message:
Fix test case to be runnable with gnupg 2.1

In gnupg 2.1 %no-ask-passphrase is a no-op.  As a result gpg attempts to
prompt for a passphrase and as the shell is not interactive it fails.

To allow gnupg 2.1 to create passphrase-less keys we enable two options
new to gnupg 2.1.

%no-protection
%transient-key

Change-Id: If687ff005cf968133fc1fa12b1259a127c464e5b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/75/188675/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gnupg_version_re = re.compile('^gpg\s.*\s([\d+]\.[\d+])') gnupg_version = base._run_cmd(['gpg', '--version'], tempdir.path) for line in gnupg_version[0].split('\n'): gnupg_version = gnupg_version_re.match(line) if gnupg_version: gnupg_version = float(gnupg_version.group(1)) break else: if gnupg_version == None: gnupg_version = 0.0 if gnupg_version >= 2.1: f.write(""" %no-protection %transient-key """) if 1.0 <= gnupg_version < 2.0: elif 2.0 <= gnupg_version:
deleted_lines: #%no-protection -- these would be ideal but they are documented #%transient-key -- but not implemented in gnupg! gnupg_version_re = re.compile('gpg .* ([12])\.') gnupg_version = base._run_cmd(['gpg', '--version'], tempdir.path) for line in gnupg_version[0].split('\n'): gnupg_version = gnupg_version_re.match(line) if gnupg_version: gnupg_version = gnupg_version.group(1) break if gnupg_version == '1': elif gnupg_version == '2':

"ds_name", None, 2 * units.Gi) def test_ds_no_capacity_no_freespace(self): ds = datastore.Datastore("fake_ref", "ds_name") self.assertIsNone(ds.capacity) self.assertIsNone(ds.freespace) def test_ds_invalid(self): self.assertRaises(ValueError, datastore.Datastore, None, "ds_name") self.assertRaises(ValueError, datastore.Datastore, "fake_ref", None) def test_build_path(self): ds = ds_url = ds.build_url('https', '10.0.0.2', path) self.assertEqual(ds_url.datastore_name, "ds_name") self.assertEqual(ds_url.datacenter_path, "dc_path") self.assertEqual(ds_url.path, path) def mock.Mock() ds.get_summary.return_value.accessible = False self.assertEqual([], ds.get_connected_hosts(session)) ds.get_summary.return_value.accessible = True m1 = HostMount("m1", self.assertTrue(datastore.Datastore.is_datastore_mount_usable(m)) m = MountInfo('read', True, True) self.assertFalse(datastore.Datastore.is_datastore_mount_usable(m)) m = MountInfo('readWrite', False, self.assertFalse(datastore.Datastore.is_datastore_mount_usable(m)) m = MountInfo('readWrite', None, True) self.assertFalse(datastore.Datastore.is_datastore_mount_usable(m)) class DatastorePathTestCase(base.TestCase): """Test the DatastorePath object.""" def test_ds_path(self): p = datastore.DatastorePath('dsname', 'a/b/c', 'file.iso') self.assertEqual('[dsname] a/b/c/file.iso', str(p)) self.assertEqual('a/b/c/file.iso', p.rel_path) self.assertEqual('a/b/c', p.parent.rel_path) self.assertEqual('[dsname] a/b/c', str(p.parent)) self.assertEqual('dsname', p.datastore) self.assertEqual('file.iso', p.basename) self.assertEqual('a/b/c', p.dirname) def test_ds_path_no_ds_name(self): bad_args = [ ('', ['a/b/c', 'file.iso']), (None, ['a/b/c', 'file.iso'])] for t in bad_args: self.assertRaises( ValueError, datastore.DatastorePath, t[0], *t[1]) def test_ds_path_invalid_path_components(self): bad_args = [ ('dsname', [None]), ('dsname', ['', None]), ('dsname', ['a', None]), ('dsname', ['a', None, 'b']), ('dsname', [None, '']), ('dsname', [None, 'b'])] for t in bad_args: self.assertRaises( ValueError, datastore.DatastorePath, t[0], *t[1]) def test_ds_path_no_subdir(self): args = [ ('dsname', ['', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['x.vmdk'])] canonical_p = datastore.DatastorePath('dsname', 'x.vmdk') self.assertEqual('[dsname] x.vmdk', str(canonical_p)) self.assertEqual('', canonical_p.dirname) self.assertEqual('x.vmdk', canonical_p.basename) self.assertEqual('x.vmdk', canonical_p.rel_path) for t in args: p = datastore.DatastorePath(t[0], *t[1]) self.assertEqual(str(canonical_p), str(p)) def test_ds_path_ds_only(self): args = [ ('dsname', []), ('dsname', ['']), ('dsname', ['', ''])] canonical_p = datastore.DatastorePath('dsname') self.assertEqual('[dsname]', str(canonical_p)) self.assertEqual('', canonical_p.rel_path) self.assertEqual('', canonical_p.basename) self.assertEqual('', canonical_p.dirname) for t in args: p = datastore.DatastorePath(t[0], *t[1]) self.assertEqual(str(canonical_p), str(p)) self.assertEqual(canonical_p.rel_path, p.rel_path) def test_ds_path_equivalence(self): args = [ ('dsname', ['a/b/c/', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['a/', 'b/c/', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['a', 'b', 'c', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['a/b/c', 'x.vmdk'])] canonical_p = datastore.DatastorePath('dsname', 'a/b/c', 'x.vmdk') for t in args: p = datastore.DatastorePath(t[0], *t[1]) self.assertEqual(str(canonical_p), str(p)) self.assertEqual(canonical_p.datastore, p.datastore) self.assertEqual(canonical_p.rel_path, p.rel_path) self.assertEqual(str(canonical_p.parent), str(p.parent)) def test_ds_path_non_equivalence(self): args = [ # leading slash ('dsname', ['/a', 'b', 'c', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['/a/b/c/', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['a/b/c', '/x.vmdk']), # leading space ('dsname', ['a/b/c/', ' x.vmdk']), ('dsname', ['a/', ' b/c/', 'x.vmdk']), ('dsname', [' a', 'b', 'c', 'x.vmdk']), # trailing space ('dsname', ['/a/b/c/', 'x.vmdk ']), ('dsname', ['a/b/c/ ', 'x.vmdk'])] canonical_p = datastore.DatastorePath('dsname', 'a/b/c', 'x.vmdk') for t in args: p = datastore.DatastorePath(t[0], *t[1]) self.assertNotEqual(str(canonical_p), str(p)) def test_equal(self): a = datastore.DatastorePath('ds_name', 'a') b = datastore.DatastorePath('ds_name', 'a') self.assertEqual(a, b) def test_join(self): p = datastore.DatastorePath('ds_name', 'a') ds_path = p.join('b') self.assertEqual('[ds_name] a/b', str(ds_path)) p = datastore.DatastorePath('ds_name', 'a') ds_path = p.join() bad_args = [ [None], ['', None], ['a', None], ['a', None, 'b']] for arg in bad_args: self.assertRaises(ValueError, p.join, *arg) def test_ds_path_parse(self): p = datastore.DatastorePath.parse('[dsname]') self.assertEqual('dsname', p.datastore) self.assertEqual('', p.rel_path) p = datastore.DatastorePath.parse('[dsname] folder') self.assertEqual('dsname', p.datastore) self.assertEqual('folder', p.rel_path) p = datastore.DatastorePath.parse('[dsname] folder/file') self.assertEqual('dsname', p.datastore) self.assertEqual('folder/file', p.rel_path) for p in [None, '']: self.assertRaises(ValueError, datastore.DatastorePath.parse, p) for p in ['bad path', '/a/b/c', 'a/b/c']: self.assertRaises(IndexError, datastore.DatastorePath.parse, p) class ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = datastore.DatastoreURL(scheme, server, path, dc_path, ds_name) expected_url = '%s://%s/folder/%s?%s' % ( scheme, server, path, query) self.assertEqual(expected_url, str(url)) def test_path_lstrip(self): scheme = 'https' server = '13.37.73.31' path = '/images/ubuntu-14.04.vmdk' dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = datastore.DatastoreURL(scheme, server, path, dc_path, ds_name) expected_url = '%s://%s/folder/%s?%s' % ( scheme, server, path.lstrip('/'), query) self.assertEqual(expected_url, str(url)) def test_path_rstrip(self): scheme = 'https' server = '13.37.73.31' path = 'images/ubuntu-14.04.vmdk/' dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = datastore.DatastoreURL(scheme, server, path, dc_path, ds_name) expected_url = '%s://%s/folder/%s?%s' % ( scheme, server, path.rstrip('/'), query) self.assertEqual(expected_url, str(url)) def test_urlparse(self): dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = 'https://13.37.73.31/folder/images/aa.vmdk?%s' % query ds_url = datastore.DatastoreURL.urlparse(url) self.assertEqual(url, str(ds_url)) def test_datastore_name(self): dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = 'https://13.37.73.31/folder/images/aa.vmdk?%s' % query ds_url = datastore.DatastoreURL.urlparse(url) self.assertEqual(ds_name, ds_url.datastore_name) def test_datacenter_path(self): dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = 'https://13.37.73.31/folder/images/aa.vmdk?%s' % query ds_url = datastore.DatastoreURL.urlparse(url) self.assertEqual(dc_path, ds_url.datacenter_path) def test_path(self): dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} path = 'images/aa.vmdk' query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = 'https://13.37.73.31/folder/%s?%s' % (path, query) ds_url = datastore.DatastoreURL.urlparse(url) self.assertEqual(path, ds_url.path) @mock.patch('six.moves.http_client.HTTPSConnection') def test_connect(self, mock_conn): dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = 'https://13.37.73.31/folder/images/aa.vmdk?%s' % query ds_url = datastore.DatastoreURL.urlparse(url) cookie = mock.Mock() ds_url.connect('PUT', 128, cookie) mock_conn.assert_called_once_with('13.37.73.31') def test_get_transfer_ticket(self): dc_path = 'datacenter-1' ds_name = 'datastore-1' params = {'dcPath': dc_path, 'dsName': ds_name} query = urlparse.urlencode(params) url = 'https://13.37.73.31/folder/images/aa.vmdk?%s' % query session = mock.Mock() session.invoke_api = mock.Mock() class Ticket(object): id = 'fake_id' session.invoke_api.return_value = Ticket() ds_url = datastore.DatastoreURL.urlparse(url) ticket = ds_url.get_transfer_ticket(session, 'PUT') self.assertEqual('%s="%s"' % (constants.CGI_COOKIE_KEY, 'fake_id'), ticket)

commit_message:
Remove versionutils

The versionutils module has graduated, so remove the incubated version
and update remaining references to the version in oslo.log.

Blueprint graduate-oslo-versionutils
Depends-On: I69a9356ac3257bfa80a4ae51ca242da4a107e21a
Change-Id: I9e49680966c2ea4f0e356fdfb4c1748b4bd25251

'_deprecated_msg_with_no_alternative_no_removal') # The first argument is the logger, and we don't care about # that, so ignore it with ANY. mock_reporter.assert_called_with(mock.ANY, expected_msg, self.assertThat(retval, matchers.Equals(expected_rv)) @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecating_a_method_returns_correct_value(self, mock_reporter): matchers.Equals((1, 'of anything'))) @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_with_unknown_future_release(self, mock_reporter): test_deprecated_with_known_future_release(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY, in_favor_of='different_stuff()') def do_outdated_stuff(): return do_outdated_stuff() self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='do_outdated_stuff()', in_favor_of='different_stuff()', as_of='Grizzly', remove_in='Icehouse') @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_without_replacement(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY) def @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_with_custom_what(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY, what='v2.0 API', in_favor_of='v3 API') def do_outdated_stuff(): return do_outdated_stuff() self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='v2.0 API', in_favor_of='v3 API', as_of='Grizzly', remove_in='Icehouse') @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_with_removed_next_release(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY, remove_in=1) def do_outdated_stuff(): return do_outdated_stuff() self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='do_outdated_stuff()', as_of='Grizzly', remove_in='Havana') @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_with_removed_plus_3(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY, remove_in=+3) def do_outdated_stuff(): return do_outdated_stuff() self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='do_outdated_stuff()', as_of='Grizzly', remove_in='Juno') @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_with_removed_zero(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY, remove_in=0) def do_outdated_stuff(): return do_outdated_stuff() self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, no_removal=True, what='do_outdated_stuff()', as_of='Grizzly', remove_in='Grizzly') @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_with_removed_zero_and_alternative(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.GRIZZLY, in_favor_of='different_stuff()', remove_in=0) def do_outdated_stuff(): return do_outdated_stuff() self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, no_removal=True, what='do_outdated_stuff()', as_of='Grizzly', in_favor_of='different_stuff()', remove_in='Grizzly') @mock.patch('openstack.common.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_class_without_init(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.JUNO, remove_in=+1) class OutdatedClass(object): pass obj = OutdatedClass() self.assertIsInstance(obj, OutdatedClass) self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='OutdatedClass()', as_of='Juno', test_requested_minor_greater(self): self.assertFalse(versionutils.is_compatible('1.1', '1.0')) def test_requested_minor_less_than(self): self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '1.1')) def test_requested_patch_greater(self): self.assertFalse(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0.1', '1.0.0')) def test_requested_patch_less_than(self): self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0.0', '1.0.1')) def test_requested_patch_not_present_same(self): self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '1.0.0')) def test_requested_patch_not_present_less_than(self): self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '1.0.1')) def test_current_patch_not_present_same(self): self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0.0', '1.0')) def test_current_patch_not_present_less_than(self): self.assertFalse(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0.1', '1.0')) def test_same_major_true(self): """Even though the current version is 2.0, since `same_major` defaults to `True`, 1.0 is deemed incompatible. """ self.assertFalse(versionutils.is_compatible('2.0', '1.0')) self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '1.0')) self.assertFalse(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '2.0')) def test_same_major_false(self): """With `same_major` set to False, then major version compatibiity rule is not enforced, so a current version of 2.0 is deemed to satisfy a requirement of 1.0. """ self.assertFalse(versionutils.is_compatible('2.0', '1.0', same_major=False)) self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '1.0', same_major=False)) self.assertTrue(versionutils.is_compatible('1.0', '2.0', same_major=False))

The following patch switches the remainder of cinder internals
to use snapshot object instead of direct db calls.  Note that
db calls within cinder drivers were not switched over.  This
is left to driver maintainers to do themselves and to
properly test out the changes on their hardware.

Also, note that there are three occurrences of
db.snapshot_update left in cinder/volume/manager.py.  This is
intentional because driver.create_cgsnapshot and
driver.delete_cgsnapshot returns a list of snapshot dicts.
cgsnapshots must be switched over to objects before these
occurrences can be safely removed and changed to use object
methods.

Change-Id: I64004ac404f67eecee51361dc8edd3f149e1b987
Implements: blueprint cinder-objects
'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-03-30 14:29:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/4ceebfd4a55c842a822942e7206bc547c3e6d69d', 'message': 'Complete switch to snapshot objects

up patch can be created to remove db.snapshot_update and
db.snapshot_destroy in cinder/volume/manager.py.  There are
bugs filed for these to be fixed -

commit_message:
Complete switch to snapshot objects

The following patch switches the remainder of cinder internals
to use snapshot object instead of direct db calls.  Note that
db calls within cinder drivers were not switched over.  This
is left to driver maintainers to do themselves and to
properly test out the changes on their hardware.

Also, note that there are three occurrences of
db.snapshot_update and one of db.snapshot_destroy left in
cinder/volume/manager.py.  This is intentional because
driver.create_cgsnapshot and driver.delete_cgsnapshot returns
a list of snapshot dicts.  Each driver needs to switched over
occurences of db.snapshot_get_all_for_cgsnapshot() to
SnapshotList.get_all_for_cgsnapshot() in create_cgsnapshot
and delete_cgsnapshot.  Once each driver has done so, a follow
up patch can be created to remove db.snapshot_update and
db.snapshot_destroy in cinder/volume/manager.py.  There are
bugs filed for these to be fixed -
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bugs?field.tag=
cgsnapshot-objects.

Change-Id: I64004ac404f67eecee51361dc8edd3f149e1b987
Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-objects

commit_message:
Clean up unused exceptions

Over the last cycle several drivers were removed. There
have also been changes over time in the code. As a
result, there were quite a few exception class declarations
that were no longer being used anywhere in the code base.

This removes Exception classes that were not referenced.

Change-Id: Ieed6e6e81196e7fe62d0ce22bab5620ac4a1269d

commit_message:
Allow provisioning to reach max oversubscription

Currently if provisioned ratio is equal to max_over_subscription_ratio,
the capacity filter does not allow any more thin provisioning. This patch
makes a change so that thin provisioning is allowed if provisioned ratio
is equal to max_over_subscription_ratio; it will only stop provisioning
if provisioned ratio is greater than max_over_subscription_ratio.

Change-Id: Ibf13ef97472b80a1b59ffd4389a4ed2eacf67205
Partial-Bug: #1458976
(cherry picked from commit ab017d98b1bb39d218bd93970c0e561c685b7dbf)

Modified exception messages to be in i18n

Used _() method from library oslo.i18n, to make all exceptions into i18n.

reported by backend matches volume_backend_name in volume type
extra specs, and if they don't, the backend would fail to pass
the filter.  Now that this side-effect has been removed, it
would impact users only under following circumstance: 1) user

is the case for user, enabling CapabilitiesFilter by adding
it to 'scheduler_default_filters' configure option and restart
cinder scheduler service then everything should work just fine.

volume_backend_name.

commit_message:
DriverFilter: don't check volume_backend_name

Currently DriverFilter checks if host_state.volume_backend_name
matches type.extra_specs.volume_backend_name.  The same check has
already been done in CapabilitiesFilter and done more thoroughly and
gracefully, for example, volume_backend_name can be a set of names
not limited to one to one match.  DriverFilter should just do one
thing, that is evaluating filter_function supplied by backend.

This change removes the volume_backend_name check from DriverFilter
without touching its core function, thus has no impact on existing
documentation because the checking of volume_backend_name is an
undocumented side-effect of this filter.  This change also reduces
one warning log to debug log when no filter_function found in
host_state, for the reason it would generate a lot of warning log
for those backends don't supply filter_function.

UpgradeImpact:
DriverFilter had an undocumented side-effect before it evaluates
filter_function - it checked if volume_backend_name in host_state
reported by backend matches volume_backend_name in volume type
extra specs, and if they don't, the backend would fail to pass
the filter.  Now that this side-effect has been removed, it
would impact users only under following circumstance: 1) user
enabled DriverFilter but not CapabilitiesFilter; 2) user relied
on DriverFilter to filter backends based on exact match of
'volume_backend_name' in type extra spec.  If unfortunately this
is the case for user, enabling CapabilitiesFilter by adding
it to 'scheduler_default_filters' configure option and restart
cinder scheduler service then everything should work just fine.
CapabilitiesFilter actually does a much better job checking
volume_backend_name.

Change-Id: Ie5c48587368856faa538eebb1b6611d464bd69bd
Closes-bug: #1461770

commit_message:
Improve Rally ACL rules

Add extra column with core plugin reviews:

 - We can split core reviewers and plugin reviewers and increase review
   throughtput (by social rules like 1 plugin reviewer + 1 core
   reviewer is enough to merge plugin patch)

 - Plugin core reviewers should be able to block changes with -2
   if something is terribly wrong

 - Any mark in core plugin reviews, except -2, is non blocking

Add rally-release group for pushing tags

Change-Id: I671d5c21186c7e1c4667f2e434c01c46ac5ebab3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/96/187196/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: label-OpenStack-Plugin-Review = -2..+1 group rally-plugin-core[label "OpenStack-Plugin-Review"] copyAllScoresOnTrivialRebase = true defaultValue = 0 function = AnyWithBlock value = -2 Do not merge value = -1 This patch needs further work before it can be merged value = 0 No score value = +1 This patch looks good to me (core plugin reviewer) value = +2 Unused +2 pushSignedTag = group rally-ptl

commit_message:
Add Pure Storage FibreChannel driver

    This commit adds a FibreChannel driver for Pure Storage. The driver shares
    the majority of functionality with base driver and only has the code
    necessary to support connection to FibreChannel.

Implements: blueprint pure-fc-driver
Change-Id: Ia4ce76d6a2ec754951c13d3620f9f47d6920058b

Normalize vendor files

Remove settings from vendor files that are covered by defaults. Also,
make sure we have the region list in each file.

Change-Id: I70003b33237f8f972a000b1d9ad27c200f7640d1

Change-Id: Id38f29c22f1ab0e1bbcf8a685e4bb656f021c6c1

commit_message:
Swift Hybrid Container Spec

Change-Id: Id38f29c22f1ab0e1bbcf8a685e4bb656f021c6c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift-specs refs/changes/28/151728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. ======================== Hybrid Container Support ======================== Swift currently allows one storage policy for a container. In a typical setup, a storage policy represents backend devices with similar service level objective (SLO) characteristics like IOPS, time-to-first-byte, RPO, RTO, etc. This conflation of logical namespace with physical resources puts the burden of placing objects based on SLO by namespace partitioning by the application i.e., store objects with SLO1 in Container1, and objects with SLO2 in Container2, etc. This reduces the flexibility of applications in utilizing containers for organizing objects into logically related buckets. We propose that Swift adopt a mechanism to allow objects within a container to be stored on backends with different SLO e.g., SSD/HDD/tape, or replicated/erasure coded. Why hybrid containers ===================== Hybrid containers provide flexibility for the application and Swift operators to enforce SLO at the object granularity. This flexibility improves TCO: 1. $/GB vs $/IOPS: Swift may choose between $/GB-optimized devices (e.g., HDD) and a $/IOPS-optimized devices (e.g., SSD) per object, based on the performance SLO requirement. 2. Availability vs replication: Swift may trade off availability for a lower replication cost. For instance, when an application requires low availability for an object that its loss can be tolerated, Swift may choose to use 2-way replication instead of 3-way, for that object. Hence, availability requirement is achieved at a lower cost. 3. Archival vs regular drives: Swift can store large objects on the archival drives (e.g., SMR), which yield better $/GB for large sequential writes, and store small objects on regular drives. Requirements ============ Object Placement based on SLO can be either: 1. Transparently stored by Swift on multiple physical backends. Swift can decide object placement based on system factors such as backend availability, capacity balancing, etc. 2. Application directed by supplying SLO requirement through a special header: X-SLO. This header could either directly specify the physical back-end or alternatively, the operator may declare some rules based on which Swift infer the appropriate backend, e.g., objects larger than a threshold to be stored on SMR drives. Suggested Implementation Option =============================== We describe sketches of a possible implementation of hybrid containers. We seek feedback from the community to craft a detailed design. Multi-backend ============= In this design, Swift spreads objects of a hybrid container across default Swift backend as well as managed storage backends where each backend is suitable for a specific SLO requirement. A managed storage backend can be a separate Swift namespace, i.e. a different account consisting of multiple containers. Each container can be configured with a storage policy catering to a specific SLO, e.g., erasure coding, 2-way replication, backed by SMR drives, etc. A managed storage backend can also be an external storage system using LTFS tape, for example. When an application attempts to store an object, the Swift Proxy server determines the appropriate backend based on the required SLO. The object is stored on the DAS backend if DAS meets the SLO requirement. Otherwise, the object is stored on the appropriate backend and a special stub/reference object is stored inside the container. The stub shares the same name as the object and contains information to locate and retrieve the actual object from the backend. A stub also stores the meta-data of the referencing object. Therefore, meta-data operations are performed on the stubs. In this way, the backend is spared from small meta-data updates, which is particularly important for archival backends such as SMR drives that are tuned for large sequential writes. Anticipated changes to Swift ============================ This blueprint can be implemented as a WSGI middleware on the Proxy server and Object server with the following (minimal) modification to object server: * Object server needs to be modified to recognize stub objects as a placeholder for an actual object that is stored somewhere else. Specifically, on PUT operation, Object servers need to pass the *object size* and *etag* of the actual object to the container servers. This information of the actual object is passed on to the Object server by the middleware as an HTTP header. Related Blueprint ================= The stub mechanism introduced in this blueprint for implementing hybrid backend is similar to the mechanism proposed in a separate blueprint on `object tiering <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/151335>`_. Similar to hybrid backend, stubs enable objects to be transparently stored/tiered across multiple physical backends.

subject: Remove entity headers on 304 response
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-26 21:17:01.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/middleware/proxy_logging.py', 'test/unit/common/middleware/test_slo.py', 'test/functional/tests.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_server.py', 'swift/common/swob.py', 'test/unit/common/middleware/test_dlo.py', 'swift/proxy/controllers/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/ad58fb8fbc784be20b26e79df48da41fc447f288', 'message': 'Remove entity headers on 304 response

As per RFC 2616 section 10.3.5 & section 4.3, 304 Not Modified
should not include entity headers like Content-Length & Content-Type.

Change-Id: I51006fe15e82acc1e3f23227f767bd802998f189
'}]
commit_message:
Remove entity headers on 304 response

As per RFC 2616 section 10.3.5 & section 4.3, 304 Not Modified
should not include entity headers like Content-Length & Content-Type.

Change-Id: I51006fe15e82acc1e3f23227f767bd802998f189
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/49/150149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: res = Response(request=req, status=source.status) if source.status == 304: res.content_length = None else: res.content_length = source.getheader('Content-Length')
deleted_lines: res = Response(request=req) res.status = source.status res.content_length = source.getheader('Content-Length')

added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================ A middle-ware that makes Swift work as an Object Storage Gateway ================================================================ This document is the specifications of the blueprint `link. <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/gateway-of-object-storage>`_ The fragment nature of Object Storage APIs slows the adopting of object storage. Maybe we can make swift as a gateway of object storage to supply an uniform API. Add an adapter to swift to transform swift APIs to other object storage APIs. Then, the data is stored in other object storage devices. Now, here is the blueprint. Let's hack out the details of the requirements. We just need a middle-ware of Swift to resolve this problem. Problem Description =================== We deploy this middle-ware inside Swift. The Swift API request is converted to other object storage API by this middle-ware. Now it only supports Amazon S3 format API. Such data can be placed directly into the S3 interface compatible object-storage devices. Only the Proxy service of Swift needs to be deployed. This combinatorial of Swift proxy server and this middle-ware can also supply the same standard of Swift API and provide external object-storage services. Ultimately, in this system, Swift does not need to do complex data persistence process, only need to implement the protocol layer of object store. It can make a variety of other object-storage devices in the back-end. Then Swift act as a role "object storage gateway" of. Proposed Change =============== The business flowchart of this system is shown below: .. image:: http://shentar.qiniudn.com/gate-way-business-flow.jpg Flowchart shown above, we extend Object\Container\Account Controller implementation, data entities corresponding mapped directly to the device at the interface of the S3 object storage device. #. We first need to export the tenant ID, user information from S3 device and into the KeyStone. Here, we provide a tool to do this work. It can import a file which contains the tenant, credentials, user information into KeyStone. Mapping between the user model is: AIM tenant corresponding Swift's Account, the user corresponds Swift AIM users. Of course, if the back-end storage devices also support the KeyStone fetch authentication information, then this does not need to import the information. #. From three resources (Object, Container and Account), each derive a subclass to transform the request to S3 API calls. #. A new Proxy Server is derived from the original one of Swift. The new subclass Proxy Server will generate specific subclass Controller at Swift process. #. Add a new Middle-ware to do the authentication of the token which the Swift client sends and obtain the corresponding EC2 style credentials from KeyStone. #. The specific subclass Controller transforms the information of the original Swift API calls into S3 API ones, coupled with previously acquired AK, SK information, generate S3 API requests. Well, this is all to be added to the Swift. This middle-ware adapter should be a stand-alone package. It depends on the realization of Swift at run time. But this adapter dos not make Swift any specific business processes to be modified, only the reuse of existing Swift code. Alternatives ------------ In other ways, we can configured Glance to support the S3 API. If the S3 API device supports authentication with KeyStone, this problem can also be resolved. But as we know, Swift object storage service provides not only internally, but also for the end user in public cloud or private cloud object storage service, which is S3-compatible devices can not do. Therefore, the use of such an independent adaptation layer to provide two interface conversion is relatively reasonable option. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: shentar1002 (tyanqun@gmail.com) Work Items ---------- N/A Repositories ------------ Suggest to create a new project repositories S3wfit for this separated. Servers ------- Use the Swift proxy servers. DNS Entries ----------- N/A Documentation ------------- We will add its own document for the project. Security -------- The transport of data from the adapter to S3 device need HTTP with SSL. Testing ------- Unit/functional tests Dependencies ============ N/A

commit_message:
Move Dothill tests out of root test directory

The Dothill code merged but unfortunately had it's
unit tests in the base tests directory.

This patch just moves it to tests/unit/volume/drivers

Change-Id: I010ed2f784384e272599ec3139957989f8838e6f
Closes-Bug: #1462106

commit_message:
Mark all current deprecations to get removed before 1.0

The active/current deprecations should not exist when version
1.0 is released so noting that in the code will let users become
aware of this so that they may prepare for it.

Change-Id: I7aac8ed96bde3532fb58927b4a78921d78999f1c

Remove listener stack and replace with exit stack

Change-Id: Ic9150b8208420d29865af297ae8d0c656becb81e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/48/182148/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: class ListenerStack(object): """Listeners that are deregistered on context manager exit. TODO(harlowja): replace this with ``contextlib.ExitStack`` or equivalent in the future (that code is in python3.2+ and in a few backports that provide nearly equivalent functionality). When/if https://review.openstack.org/#/c/164222/ merges we should be able to remove this since listeners are already context managers. """ def __init__(self, log): self._registered = [] self._log = log def register(self, listeners): for listener in listeners: listener.register() self._registered.append(listener) def __enter__(self): return self def __exit__(self, type, value, tb): while self._registered: listener = self._registered.pop() try: listener.deregister() except Exception: self._log.warn("Failed deregistering listener '%s'", listener, exc_info=True)

commit_message:
Add a test that checks for task result visibility

Now that a task can provide the same thing that it
requires, having a nice little test that ensures what
is gotten is expected in a nice manner should be done
to make sure what a task will be getting for its arguments
respect the scoping that is defined by the flow ordering.

Change-Id: I1cdc5c3bd3f56b39f20f28f51c36017405150cea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/00/186600/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_many_results_visible_to(self): flow = lf.Flow("flow") flow.add(utils.AddOne('a')) flow.add(utils.AddOne('b', rebind={'source': 'result'})) flow.add(utils.AddOne('c', rebind={'source': 'result'})) engine = self._make_engine(flow, store={'source': 0}) engine.run() # Check what each task in the prior should be seeing... atoms = list(flow) a = atoms[0] a_kwargs = engine.storage.fetch_mapped_args(a.rebind, atom_name='a') self.assertEqual({'source': 0}, a_kwargs) b = atoms[1] b_kwargs = engine.storage.fetch_mapped_args(b.rebind, atom_name='b') self.assertEqual({'source': 1}, b_kwargs) c = atoms[2] c_kwargs = engine.storage.fetch_mapped_args(c.rebind, atom_name='c') self.assertEqual({'source': 2}, c_kwargs)

commit_message:
Use shared '_check' function to check engine stages

Change-Id: I48e5efdb28ee834666ec1eca18f35f245de340d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/16/187016/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _check(self, name, check_compiled, check_storage_ensured): """Check (and raise) if the engine has not reached a certain stage.""" if check_compiled and not self._compiled: raise exc.InvalidState("Can not %s an engine which" " has not been compiled" % name) if check_storage_ensured and not self._storage_ensured: raise exc.InvalidState("Can not %s an engine" " which has not has its storage" " populated" % name) def suspend(self): self._check('suspend', True, False) self._check('validate', True, True) self._check('prepare', True, False)
deleted_lines: def suspend(self): if not self._compiled: raise exc.InvalidState("Can not suspend an engine" " which has not been compiled") if not self._storage_ensured: raise exc.InvalidState("Can not validate an engine" " which has not has its storage" " populated") if not self._compiled: raise exc.InvalidState("Can not prepare an engine" " which has not been compiled")

commit_message:
Allow periodics to run in parallel (WIP/Exploratory)

Change-Id: I4427e7e5d468e9ea98286e58dc26e5e309049c92

added_lines: import functoolsimport threading from oslo_utils import excutilsfrom taskflow.types import futures from taskflow.utils import deprecation @deprecation.removed_kwarg('tombstone', version="0.8", removal_version="?") self._immediates, self._schedule = self._prime(self._callables) self._waiter = threading.Condition() def _prime(callables): indexed_callables = list(enumerate(callables)) for i, (cb, cb_name) in reversed(indexed_callables): if cb._periodic_run_immediately: immediates.append(i) schedule = [] if len(immediates) < len(callables): now = _now() for i, (cb, cb_name) in enumerate(callables): if i in immediates: continue spacing = cb._periodic_spacing next_run = now + spacing heapq.heappush(schedule, (next_run, i)) return (immediates, schedule) """Starts running (will not stop/return until stopped). def on_finish(next_run, i, fut): with self._waiter: heapq.heappush(self._schedule, (next_run, i)) self._waiter.notify_all() def call(cb, cb_name, spacing, kind='periodic'): LOG.blather("Calling %s callable '%s' (it runs" " every %s seconds)", kind, cb_name, spacing) try: cb() except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.warn("Failed to call %s callable '%s'", kind, cb_name, exc_info=True) def submit_or_wait_next(executor): # Figure out when we should run next (by selecting the # minimum item from the heap, where the minimum should be # the callable that needs to run next and has the lowest # next desired run time). next_run, i = heapq.heappop(self._schedule) now = _now() when_next = next_run - now if when_next <= 0: cb, cb_name = self._callables[i] spacing = cb._periodic_spacing LOG.blather("Submitting periodic callable '%s' (it" " runs every %s seconds)", cb_name, spacing) fut = executor.submit(call, cb, cb_name, spacing) fut.add_done_callback(functools.partial(on_finish, now + spacing, i)) else: heapq.heappush(self._schedule, (next_run, i)) if not self._tombstone.is_set(): self._waiter.wait(when_next) def submit_immediate(executor): i = self._immediates.pop() now = _now() cb, cb_name = self._callables[i] spacing = cb._periodic_spacing LOG.blather("Submitting immediate callable '%s'", cb_name) fut = executor.submit(call, cb, cb_name, spacing, kind='immediate') fut.add_done_callback(functools.partial(on_finish, now + spacing, i)) with futures.SynchronousExecutor() as executor: while not self._tombstone.is_set(): if self._immediates: submit_immediate(executor) else: with self._waiter: while (not self._schedule and not self._tombstone.is_set()): self._waiter.wait() if not self._tombstone.is_set(): submit_or_wait_next(executor) executor.shutdown() LOG.debug("Executor finished: %s", executor.statistics) """Sets the tombstone & notify (this stops any further executions).""" with self._waiter: self._waiter.notify_all() self._immediates, self._schedule = self._prime(self._callables)

commit_message:
Fix remaining memory issues with nfs backup unit tests

Here we fix another place in the nfs backup unit tests where
the configured file size was larger than the chunk size in
the corresponding Swift backup tests.  I missed this one in

   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/165394

and even though code with that fix ran fine in a bare 1GB VM,
there are still memory issues when run in CI with a VM of that
size.

Closes-Bug: 1452811
Change-Id: I20dcfb657699e1b415ae2e36ec63f8c6b0049285

Add notes to the README about Bandit on Python 3.4

Change-Id: I6cc420898fc5654486c5b57aca0e362d9d5a5ce8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/87/188187/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Or, if you're working with a Python 3 project pip3.4 install bandit tox -e py34Under Which Version of Python Should I Install Bandit? ------------------------------------------------------ The answer to this question depends on the project(s) you will be running Bandit against. If you're project is only compatible with Python 2.7, you should install Bandit to run under Python 2.7. If your project is only compatible with Python 3.4, then use 3.4. If your project supports both, you *could* run Bandit with both versions but you don't have to. Bandit uses the `ast` module from Python's standard library in order to analyze your Python code. The `ast` module can only parse that is valid for the version of Python it is running from. In other words, if you try to use Python 2.7's `ast` module to parse code written for 3.4 that uses `yield from` with asyncio, then you'll have syntax errors that will prevent Bandit from working properly. Alternatively, if you're relying on 2.7's octal notation of `0777` then you'll have a syntax error if you run Bandit on 3.4.

commit_message:
StorPool: implement volume retyping and migrations

initialize_connection(): store the StorPool client ID in the connection
data to be used by the "StorPool" Brick connector.

validate_connector(): actually check the connector data for a valid
hostname defined in the StorPool configuration.

_storpool_client_id(): new method to get the numeric ID of a host in
the StorPool cluster from the /etc/storpool.conf file.

_attach_volume(), _detach_volume(): if the "remote" flag is set, pass
the request on to the default Cinder driver implementation; it knows
how to make remote volumes accessible.

_attach_volume(), _detach_volume(): support the case when these methods
are invoked from a method that is not overridden in the StorPool Cinder
driver - create a storpool.spopenstack.AttachDB attachment structure
and destroy it upon detaching.

ensure_export(): add a stub method, the actual work is handled by
the Nova volume attachment driver.

retype(): new method: handle a StorPool-to-StorPool retyping where
at most the volume's StorPool template or replication is changed.
For anything else, return False to indicate an unsupported request so
that a full volume migration is triggered.

update_migrated_volume(): rename the StorPool volume to correspond to
the real Cinder volume's name.

Add the StorPoolConfigurationMissing and StorPoolConfigurationInvalid
exceptions.

Flesh out the validate_connector() and initialize_connection() unit tests.

Implements: blueprint volume-retype
Change-Id: I82925c2bf45dff839706f518d4d790b8596ff492
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/30/188730/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # StorPool driver class StorPoolConfigurationMissing(CinderException): message = _("Missing parameter %(param)s in the %(section)s section " "of the /etc/storpool.conf file") class StorPoolConfigurationInvalid(CinderException): message = _("Invalid parameter %(param)s in the %(section)s section " "of the /etc/storpool.conf file: %(error)s")

commit_message:
StorPool: fall back to the configured template

If the volume type does not specify a template, properly fall back to
the default template from the configuration instead of going with none.

commit_message:
Removed explicit return from __init__ method

As per python documentation [1], removed explicit return keyword
from __init__ method.

[1] https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__init__

Closes-Bug: 1461931
Change-Id: I654d7786e1971304789bbb376f8ced2b5646370e

commit_message:
[rally-jobs] Change import of base context

Rally team wants to change structure of context module[*] and doesn't want to
break ec2 gates, so this patch adds try...except block to cover old structure
and new one.

try...except block should be removed, after patch in Rally will be merged.

[*] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/188518/

Also, this patch fixes wrong import of rally network wrapper

Depends-On: I29c2dd5f85dc8b0a59d9b3f0ea86ff3edf0a7953
Change-Id: I4a012c994dbbc6320f6d3c6b1537b47c6f1579e5

commit_message:
devstack/settings: Do not configure passwords here

Because openrc doesn't honour them.
They are user settings more suitable to local.conf anyway.

Closes-Bug: #1462166
Change-Id: Ifeb5a0be905688f401d223fc9c67d17999a7d5af

commit_message:
ngReorg - move dashboard controllers from horizon

This change moves the controller ImageFormCtrl and
hzNamespaceResourceTypeFormController from horizon (the framework)
to openstack_dashboard (the application) where they belong.

commit_message:
Change new input task format specification

We have issue with current format there are 2 things called "task",
"task" is file with bunch of "task" that are run.

I would prefer to split these 2 things:

  task - is file that is run by "rally task" command

  subtasks - is actually single test case described in task file

Change-Id: Ib1a2f39bb91cfb5b0ba0b3d15be53d3a3241bfc7

added_lines: self._set_invalid_task_result(log) def _set_invalid_task_result(self, log): results = [] results.append(base_runner.ScenarioRunnerResult( {"duration":0, "scenario_output": {"errors": "", "data": {}}, "idle_duration": 0, "atomic_actions": [], "error": log})) for name in self.config: for n, kw in enumerate(self.config[name]): key = {'name': name, 'pos': n, 'kw': kw} self.task.append_results(key, {"raw": results, "scenario_duration": 0})

commit_message:
Add fuel client and scenarios.

It is WIP and will not work withou custom fuel python client

Change-Id: Iad80831e700def3bd820aecc418dadff6f661bb5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/55/127955/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from fuelclient.client import Client as FuelClient def fuel(self): """Return fuel client.""" kc = self.keystone() fuel_api_url = kc.service_catalog.url_for( service_type='fuel', endpoint_type='public', region_name=self.endpoint.region_name) client = FuelClient() client.api_root = fuel_api_url + '/' client.auth_token = kc.auth_token return client

commit_message:
Basic scenarios for Ironic API

Implemented scenarios that allow to benchmark:
 - Creating a chassis
 - Creating and validating a node.

Change-Id: Ia8cda676545a4fae08232f954625011eaf5eca8d

commit_message:
tempest: add `admin_domain_name' to generated conf

Add admin_domain_name=default of autogenerated tempest.conf
This line prevents the keystone v3 related tests to be declared as failure.

Closes-Bug:1460680

Change-Id: I9e0eeb2e9392df17fc0e0c71bf9268482e921ac9
Signed-off-by: morganrOL <morgan.richomme@orange.com>

test_ovs_neutron_agent: Remove useless ofport=10 arguments

The kwarg ofport has been removed from method signatures
where it was never used.

commit_message:
Add the Designate DNSaaS services.

This is a complete DNS solution, with hidden master and bind9 slave.

It lacks the designate-sink service, because there is no true specification
to implement that. It listens for Nova/Neutron events and creates records
though adding those to just 1 domain isn't helping much in an environment
with multiple tenants.

Change-Id: I500fb6058b118d25a4ccfd1d3479830c36af7e2a
Blueprint: designate-container

commit_message:
Added `npm run lint` command to execute JSCS

This patch adds jscs as an npm dependency, and executes it within
the npm venv. It can be used to trigger the infra npm-run-lint job
and thus get voting javascript code linting into infra.

Change-Id: I2c92a7596a8faee28de582493bdf72425deac8cc

deleted_lines: def assertRaisesRegexp(self, expected_exception, expected_regexp, callable_obj, *args, **kwargs): """Asserts that the message in a raised exception matches a regexp. """ try: callable_obj(*args, **kwargs) except expected_exception as exc_value: if isinstance(expected_regexp, six.string_types): expected_regexp = re.compile(expected_regexp) if isinstance(exc_value.args[0], unicode): if not expected_regexp.search(unicode(exc_value)): raise self.failureException( '"%s" does not match "%s"' % (expected_regexp.pattern, unicode(exc_value))) else: if not expected_regexp.search(str(exc_value)): raise self.failureException( '"%s" does not match "%s"' % (expected_regexp.pattern, str(exc_value))) else: if hasattr(expected_exception, '__name__'): excName = expected_exception.__name__ else: excName = str(expected_exception) raise self.failureException("%s not raised" % excName) def assertDictContainsSubset(self, expected, actual, msg=None): """Checks whether actual is a superset of expected.""" def safe_repr(obj, short=False): _MAX_LENGTH = 80 try: result = repr(obj) except Exception: result = object.__repr__(obj) if not short or len(result) < _MAX_LENGTH: return result return result[:_MAX_LENGTH] + ' [truncated]...' missing = [] mismatched = [] for key, value in six.iteritems(expected): if key not in actual: missing.append(key) elif value != actual[key]: mismatched.append('%s, expected: %s, actual: %s' % (safe_repr(key), safe_repr(value), safe_repr(actual[key]))) if not (missing or mismatched): return standardMsg = '' if missing: standardMsg = 'Missing: %s' % ','.join(safe_repr(m) for m in missing) if mismatched: if standardMsg: standardMsg += '; ' standardMsg += 'Mismatched values: %s' % ','.join(mismatched) self.fail(self._formatMessage(msg, standardMsg))

commit_message:
Add support to get a SwiftService object

This adds a property of the cloud, swift_service, for the purpose of
enabling uploads via SwiftService's more advanced segmenting
capabilities.

In writing tests, it became clear that cloud.swift_client was leaking
exceptions, which we don't want it to do, which is why we add exception
handling to that method.

Change-Id: I045266e6d5f0b6bed3100905ada6ab35fbb06987

commit_message:
Add delete method for security groups

Adds the API method to delete a security group, using nova or neutron,
and consolidates existing and new security group tests into a new file.

Change-Id: Ib85b3ec0de8b2b42f691c3e2127adb16e8b14c99
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/36/188636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NeutronSecurityGroupDelete(task_manager.Task): def main(self, client): return client.neutron_client.delete_security_group(**self.args) class NovaSecurityGroupDelete(task_manager.Task): def main(self, client): return client.nova_client.security_groups.delete(**self.args)

subject: Move postcommit ops out of transaction for bulk
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-13 19:24:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6f487450591735d3c624a2a146b21348abcdafec', 'message': 'Move postcommit ops out of transaction for bulk

Currently, the bulk create operations in ML2 are executed in
a transaction. This means all precommit and postcommit operations
for such operations are in a transaction. Postcommit operations
are expected to be executed outside of transactions as they may
communicate with a backend and introduce substantial delays. This
fix removes the postcommit operations from the transaction for
bulk create network operation. Bulk create ops for subnets and
ports are to be fixed using the same approach in a future patch set
or as seperate patches.

Change-Id: I9a9683058088e50d9443040223232bf5e1396ccf
Partial-Bug: #1193861

commit_message:
Move postcommit ops out of transaction for bulk

Currently, the bulk create operations in ML2 are executed in
a transaction. This means all precommit and postcommit operations
for such operations are in a transaction. Postcommit operations
are expected to be executed outside of transactions as they may
communicate with a backend and introduce substantial delays. This
fix removes the postcommit operations from the transaction for
bulk create network/subnet/port operations.

Change-Id: I9a9683058088e50d9443040223232bf5e1396ccf
Closes-Bug: #1193861

commit_message:
Fix req.environ[SCRIPT_NAME] value.

The computation done inside 
/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/routes/middleware.py 
was leaving req.environ[SCRIPT_NAME] with a wrong value with 
a repeated text block. No code in keystone seems to use the 
value of this variable, hence it has escaped detection until
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/177427/ which logs req URLs 
by using SCRIPT_NAME in the url construction (via
wsgiref.util.request_uri()).

I backtraced the execution flow to the middleware.py file 
from the keystone middleware components. Prepending a '/' 
to the mapper path used in the ExtensionsRouter seems harmless 
as well as seems to fix the problem. 

See log files before and after, from sample Jenkins runs.

BEFORE: http://goo.gl/YI89e4
AFTER (for this review): http://goo.gl/I1qVaI

Closes-Bug:#1454968

Change-Id: Ia9bf1e1644c996e5aa71ac4e634ead3c4de7edcf

commit_message:
Added karma-cli to package.json

Turns out that npm runs a little like venv's do, in that it can
install executables in its own path. This adds the karma-cli
executable into the npm path, and removes additional extraneous
content from the package.json file.

Change-Id: Ib25553956a9757ecbb1ee7ce722f3646ededc035

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-20 07:02:32.000000000', 'files': ['swift/cli/recon.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/b568477612a0390a9f4e1811d9302a55265f70a3', 'message': "Fix swift-recon --auditor bug

Schwede uncovered.  Christian proposed a fix which replaces the
generator nested_get_value with a recursive function which
returns just one instance of a key.  Christian's fix will break

commit_message:
Fix swift-recon --auditor bug

I introduced a bug in swift-recon --auditor, which Christian
Schwede uncovered.  Christian proposed a fix which replaces the
generator nested_get_value with a recursive function which
returns just one instance of a key.  Christian's fix will break
the parallel object auditor patch which uses the generator to
return all instances of a particular key in a nested dictionary
and then sums those values.

This alternative fix sums over all values returned by
nested_get_value, as is done in the parallel auditor patch.

Change-Id: I6ac403395ab42d11161d6df266e8fbd5a2af9a64
(cherry picked from commit 203515718a2bee8334bd4936201f00a929ccbd89)

commit_message:
Add functional test for --plugin-paths parameter

Change-Id: I3a847ae490657be47b11cc178692658d8304556e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/07/183507/24 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_plugin_paths(self): pass def test_start_with_plugin_paths(self): rally = utils.Rally() with mock.patch.dict("os.environ", utils.TEST_ENV): deployment_id = envutils.get_global("RALLY_DEPLOYMENT") cfg = self._get_sample_task_config() config = utils.TaskConfig(cfg) plugin_paths = self._get_plugin_paths() output = rally(("task start --task %(task_file)s " "--deployment %(deployment_id)s"" "--plugin-paths %(plugin-paths)s") % {"task_file": config.filename, "deployment_id": deployment_id, "plugin_paths": plugin_paths}) result = re.search( r"(?P<task_id>[0-9a-f\-]{36}): started", output) self.assertIsNotNone(result)

commit_message:
Make plugins location configurable

The patch introduces CLI option --plugin-paths to specify the list of
folders with plugins.

Co-Authored-By: Roman Vasilets <rvasilets@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ilya Shakhat <ishakhat@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Iee39217bfe3e5c77e6925910f3998942541387a3

commit_message:
remove old tombstone(.ts)

Check tombstone in object-auditor, call invalidate_hash if found.

Since auditor now uses the reclaim_age as well as the replicator,
relocate the configuration variable into the [DEFAULT] section.

Closes-Bug: 1301728
Change-Id: I58c7377730cba2e885453ec24637f33318b6f7de
Modified-By: Pete Zaitcev <zaitcev@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/55/134855/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._reclaim_age = mgr.reclaim_age # If the tombstone's too old, call invalidate_hash basename = os.path.basename(ts_file) ts = basename.rsplit('.', 1)[0] if (time.time() - float(Timestamp(ts))) > self._reclaim_age: suffix_dir = os.path.dirname(ts_file) suffix_dir = os.path.dirname(suffix_dir) self._logger.warn("Found old ts file %s, invalidate_hash on %s") % (ts_file, suffix_dir) invalidate_hash(suffix_dir)

commit_message:
Updated from global requirements

Also update hacking to

    hacking>=0.10.0,<0.11

to get around breakage with pbr dependency.

Change-Id: Ic5e2d8df6993397ee4d1b087d96cc6667bd72acc

commit_message:
Let GET/HEAD on object fail in deleted account.

Until now the GET/HEAD was successful on object of
deleted account. Now this patch will check for
the existence of container (which also checks
the existence of account) on object GET/HEAD and
return 404 if it doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I4f4192ef0c2fad5839308ce22027915a62576715
Closes-Bug: 1381541

commit_message:
support for keystone v3 api - the service resource

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support
This patch implements these parts of the blueprint:
1) Implements support for the keystone_service resource using
the v3 api.  With v3, service create requires the _type_, not
the _name_, so create has been changed accordingly.  Also note
that service list with the v3 api does not take the --long
argument, but all of the same information is there as it is with
the v2 service list --long.  The service id is used with destroy
and set rather than the name.  All of these implementation details
are hidden from manifests, which should continue to work the same
as before.

Change-Id: Ia06dfb75f6e166d04ad151c87064ece85c7a8271
Co-Authored-By: Rich Megginson <rmeggins@redhat.com>
